questions.text: From which period of embryogenesis does the liver become the chief site of hematopoiesis?
questions.solution:
From the 3rd month of embryogenesis, the liver becomes the chief site of hematopoiesis.

Development of hematopoietic tissues: 

  • Yolk sac - blood cell progenitors first appear during the 3rd week
  • Liver - hematopoietic stem cells migrate to the liver during the 3rd month of embryogenesis
  • Bone marrow - hematopoiesis starts in bone marrow during the 4th month of intrauterine life and becomes the predominant site after birth

questions.text: Which cells in the bone marrow are referred to as nurse cells?
questions.solution: Nurse cells are specialized macrophages in the bone marrow that assist in the development of red blood cells (RBCs).

questions.text: Bone marrow biopsy of a normal adult is given below. What is the ratio of structures marked A and B?
questions.solution:
The structures marked A are fat cells and B are hematopoietic elements. The normal ratio of fat cells to hematopoietic elements in a normal adult is 1:1. 

In hypoplastic states (like aplastic anemia), the proportion of fat cells is greatly increased (increased fat to cell ratio).

Conversely, fat cells often disappear in conditions like hematopoietic tumors and in diseases with compensatory hyperplasias (like hemolytic anemias) and neoplastic proliferations such as leukemias (decreased fat-to-cell ratio).

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker for pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells?
questions.solution: CD34 is an antigen of pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells and progenitor cells of many lineages.

questions.text: Which of the following is called leukocyte common antigen?
questions.solution:
CD45 is called leukocyte common antigen because it is found in all leukocytes.

Related Pearl: Immune Cell Antigens Detected by Monoclonal Antibodies

Antigen Designation and their Normal Cellular Distribution 
Primarily T-Cell Associated 
  • CD1 Thymocytes and Langerhans cells 
  • CD3 Thymocytes, mature T cells 
  • CD4 Helper T cells, subset of thymocytes  
  • CD5 T cells and a small subset of B cells  
  • CD8 Cytotoxic T cells, subset of thymocytes, and some NK cells 
Primarily B-Cell Associated 
  • CD10 Pre-B cells and germinal-center B cells 
  • CD19 Pre-B cells and mature B cells, but not plasma cells 
  • CD20 Pre-B cells after CD19 and mature B cells, but not plasma cells 
  • CD21 EBV receptor; mature B cells and follicular dendritic cells
  • CD23 Activated mature B cells 
  • CD79a Marrow pre-B cells and mature B cells 
Primarily Monocyte or Macrophage Associated 
  • CD11c Granulocytes, monocytes, and macrophages; also expressed by hairy cell leukemias 
  • CD13 Immature and mature monocytes and granulocytes 
  • CD14 Monocytes 
  • CD15 Granulocytes; Reed-Sternberg cells and variants
  • CD33 Myeloid progenitors and monocytes  
  • CD64 Mature myeloid cells  
Primarily NK-CellAssociated 
  • CD16 NK cells and granulocytes  
  • CD56 NK cells and a subset of T cells 
Primarily Stem Cell and Progenitor Cell Associated  
  • CD34 Pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells and progenitor cells of many lineages 
Activation Markers 
  • CD30 Activated B cells, T cells, and monocytes; Reed-Sternberg cells and variants 
Present on All Leukocytes 
  • CD45 All leukocytes; also known as leukocyte common antigen (LCA)

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Kostmann syndrome?
questions.solution:
Kostmann syndrome is characterized by neutropenia.

It is a rare congenital condition in which inherited defects in specific genes impair granulocytic differentiation. This results in severe congenital neutropenia.

It presents in young children as recurrent bacterial infections (such as otitis media, cellulitis) and oral ulcers. It is associated with an increased risk of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

questions.text: What is the most common cause of agranulocytosis?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of agranulocytosis is drug toxicity.

Causes of agranulocytosis include:

  • Inadequate or ineffective granulopoiesis -
    • Suppression of hematopoietic stem cells - aplastic anemia, infiltrative marrow disorders
    • Suppression of committed granulocytic precursors
    • Ineffective hematopoiesis - megaloblastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndromes
    • Congenital conditions - Kostmann syndrome
  • Increased destruction or sequestration of neutrophils -
    • Immunological injury to neutrophils - idiopathic, systemic lupus erythematosus, drug exposure
    • Increased peripheral utilization - bacterial, fungal, or rickettsial infections
    • Splenomegaly

questions.text: A patient who was started on chemotherapy 2 weeks ago is found to have a neutrophil count of 2000/mm3. Below what neutrophil count is he at risk of developing serious infections?
questions.solution: Serious infections are most likely when the neutrophil count falls below 500/mm3.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought with complaints of episodes of severe, violent coughs, followed by a high-pitch intake of breath that sounds like a whoop. These coughing episodes are usually followed by vomiting. He and his family are refugees and his prior vaccination records are not available. Lab investigations of this child will likely reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of whooping cough or pertussis. It is due to Bordetella pertussis infection and results in lymphocytosis.

Causes of lymphocytosis include:

  • Pertussis 
  • Tuberculosis
  • Brucellosis
  • Hepatitis A
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Epstein-Barr virus

questions.text: A 50-year-old man admitted to ICU develops sepsis 3 days after insertion of a central venous catheter. A peripheral blood smear reveals the following. What does the structure marked by the arrow indicate?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear, prepared from an individual with bacterial sepsis, shows reactive changes in neutrophils. The arrow-marked structure is a Döhle body.

Reactive changes in neutrophils associated with leukocytosis in severe inflammatory disorders are:

  • Toxic granules, which are coarser and darker than the normal neutrophilic granules, represent abnormal azurophilic (primary) granules
  • Döhle bodies are patches of the dilated endoplasmic reticulum that appear as sky-blue cytoplasmic puddles
  • Toxic cytoplasmic vacuoles 

The image given below shows a neutrophil with cytoplasmic vacuoles.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause follicular hyperplasia of the lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
B-cell lymphoma results in malignant proliferation within the lymph node, not follicular hyperplasia.

Follicular hyperplasia is a benign condition caused by stimuli that activate humoral immune responses. It may occur in: 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Early stages of HIV infection

It is defined by the presence of large oblong germinal centres (secondary follicles), which are surrounded by a collar of small, resting naive B cells (mantle zone).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of reactive lymphoid hyperplasia?

choices.text: No variation in shape and size of the follicles

questions.solution:
In reactive lymphoid hyperplasia, there is marked variation in the shape and size of follicles.

Features favoring reactive lymphoid hyperplasia, which are absent in neoplastic follicles are:

  • Preservation of the lymph node architecture, including the interfollicular T-cell zones and the sinusoids
  • Marked variation in the shape and size of the follicles
  • Presence of frequent mitotic figures and phagocytic macrophages
  • Recognizable light and dark zones

questions.text: In which of the following organs are tingible body macrophages found?
questions.solution:
Tingible-body macrophages are found in lymph nodes.

A tingible-body macrophage is a type of macrophage predominantly found in germinal centers containing many phagocytosed apoptotic cell debris. This debris is referred to as tingible bodies (tingible meaning stainable). The presence of these macrophages suggests non-neoplastic reactive hyperplasia of the lymph node, or can be seen as the stars in the starry sky appearance of Burkitt lymphoma.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with complaints of fever, sore throat, and enlarged lymph nodes. Paul Bunnell's test was done and found to be positive. What type of lymphoid hyperplasia is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis. Acute viral infections, like infectious mononucleosis, produce paracortical hyperplasia.

There are three types of lymph node hyperplasia. They are:

  • Follicular hyperplasia
  • Paracortical hyperplasia
  • Sinus histiocytosis (reticular hyperplasia)

Paracortical hyperplasia is seen in the T-cell-containing paracortical region of the lymph node. It is caused by stimuli that trigger T-cell–mediated immune responses. The involved regions typically contain:

  • Immunoblasts
  • Activated T-cells 3-4 times the size of resting lymphocytes t
    • Round nuclei
    • Open chromatin
    • Several prominent nucleoli
    • Moderate amounts of pale cytoplasm
  • Hypertrophy of sinusoidal and vascular endothelial cells, with infiltrating macrophages and eosinophils

questions.text: In patients with breast cancer with lymph node metastases, which of the following changes is seen in affected lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
In the case of lymph node metastases, there is prominent reticular hyperplasia.

Reticular hyperplasia or sinus histiocytosis refers to an increase in the number and size of the cells that line lymphatic sinusoids. Although nonspecific, this form of hyperplasia may be particularly prominent in lymph nodes draining cancers such as carcinoma of the breast. 

The lining lymphatic endothelial cells are markedly hypertrophied and macrophages are greatly increased in numbers, resulting in the expansion and distension of the sinuses.

The image given below shows reticular hyperplasia in the lymph node.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis is false?

choices.text: There is systemic activation of macrophages and CD8+ T cells
The most common trigger is infection with Epstein-Barr virus
It presents as an acute febrile illness with hepatosplenomegaly
Hemophagocytosis seen in bone marrow is sufficient for diagnosis

questions.solution:
Hemophagocytosis is usually seen on bone marrow examination, but it is neither sufficient nor required to make the diagnosis of hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH).

HLH is a reactive condition also known as macrophage-activation syndrome. The common feature of all forms of HLH is the systemic activation of macrophages and CD8+ T-cells.  

The most common trigger for HLH is an infection, particularly with EBV (Epstein-Barr virus). It is characterized by acute febrile illness associated with splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and cytopenias.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature in patients with hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis?
questions.solution:
Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) is associated with very high serum ferritin levels.

Laboratory findings in HLH include:

  • Anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • High serum ferritin
  • High plasma IL2 receptor levels
  • Elevated liver enzyme levels
  • High triglyceride levels
  • Features of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
